LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: cakal bakal (cakal bakal) : K.N. de eerste ontginner van een grond; de eerste aanlegger of stichter van een dorp op plaats; de voorouders [vrg. akal bakal]. Sumber: Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
leluhur pertama (cikal-bakal) yang membantu membangun masyarakat dan agama Tengger dengan memberikan nyawanya untuk melindungi mereka. nenek moyang dihormati dan diperingati dan beberapa di antaranya dikaitkan dengan kekuatan supernatural yang istimewa (Jasper, 1927: 20). "Sosok cikal bakal desa hingga kini masih mendapat tempat yang istimewa dalam kehidupan masyarakat Tengger. Nama-nama mereka senantiasa disebut dalam setiap gelaran hajatan, khususnya dalam ujub
selamatan. Tempat-tempat yang diyakini sebagai makam mereka tidak hanya dipelihara, tetapi juga tempat ziarah wajib." (Sukmawan, 2018:92).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Cikal bakal adalah leluhur pertama yang membuka, mendirikan, dan menghidupi sebuah wilayah atau komunitas, terutama desa, dan dihormati sebagai pendiri spiritual serta pelindung awal masyarakat. Dalam tradisi Tengger, cikal bakal tidak hanya dipandang sebagai perintis secara fisik, tetapi juga sebagai figur sakral yang menyerahkan hidupnya demi keselamatan bersama. Namanya senantiasa disebut dalam doa selamatan, dan makamnya menjadi pusat ziarah serta penghormatan lintas generasi.
LEXICON.translation: Cikal bakal refers to the first ancestor who opened, established, and sustained a territory or community, particularly a village who is honored as the spiritual founder and original protector of the community. In Tengger tradition, cikal bakal is not only regarded as a physical pioneer but also as a sacred figure who dedicated their life to the collective well-being. Their name is continually invoked in communal prayers, and their grave becomes a center of pilgrima\ge and intergenerational reverence.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Agama dan Kepercayaan Tengger dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Semedi ini dalam rangka untuk mendekatkan diri kepada sang pencipta dengan melaku kan dzikir atau tadabur alam di berbagai tempat yang dianggap dapat mengantarkan kepada puncak kenikmatan dengan mendekatkan diri kepada Sang Mahakuasa. Ada beberapa tempat yang digunakan untuk semadi oleh warok Ponorogo, di antaranya Watu Dukun Sampung Ponorogo, Goa Lawa Sampung, Petilasan Sunan Kumbul Sawoo, dan beberapa tempat lainnya yang tersebar di Ponorogo. Tempat-tempat itu biasanya menjadi tempat penggemblengan spiritual.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
Slametan dalam konteks masyarakat subetnik Jawa Ponoragan pada Paguyuban Reog Ponorogo terekspresi dalam bentuk syukuran atau ruwatan yang dipimpin oleh warok atau sesepuh dalam paguyuban Reog dengan menggelar doa keselamatan yang ditujukan kepada suatu hal tertentu dengan tujuan diadakan slametan, seperti kirim leluhur generasi terhadulu, gebyagan Reog, atau ritual tolak balak sehingga hajat yang akan dikehendaki berjalan lancar tiada suatu halangan apa pun. 
Selain itu, juga mendoakan orang yang telah tiada sebagai bentuk mbekteni marang leluhur dan yang tidak kalah penting adalah sedekah dengan suguh, lungguh, dan aruh. Maksudnya adalah, suguh ‘hidangan’ dalam rangka menghormati tetamu. Lungguh ‘duduk’ sebagai wujud memuliakan tetamu, dan aruh ‘sapa’ sebagai ekspresi menjalin keakraban dan mempererat jalinan komunikasi.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: puja (pujO) : (S) kn. pangaji-aji, panêmbah, donga di-[x]: 1 dipêpundhi, dikurmati bangêt (tmr. marang dewa, ent. tmr. kang kinasihan) 2 br. dianakake sarana cipta (sêmadi) dipujakake ak: didongakake, dipujèkake pujan br: dadine (anane) sarana dipuja pêpujan br: 1 sêsêmbahan, kang diaji-aji (dewa) 2 kang kinasih bangêt. Sumber: Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
“Pujan, From the Sanskrit and Old Javanese term for "worship," Tengger pujan are celebrated in the fourth, eighth, ninth, and twelfth months of the Tengger calendar year; several villages celebrate a fifth pujan in the seventh month, in addition. Once marked by feasting at the village priest's house, pujan today involve a brief invocation and meal at the priest's house. Supported by food contributions from all households in the village, attendance is restricted to village officials and the priest” (Hefner, 1989:112-113).
"The pujan illustrates this pattern clearly, and also shows to what degree ordinary villagers are drawn into the ceremony... The actual ritual service—a more or less standard invocation of the gods—lasts only about five minutes. The remainder of the evening is devoted to the meal... The pujan circuit is completed the following morning. Trays of cooked food (ater-ater) are sent from the priest’s house to village officials, and small earth offerings are set out by the roadside, cemetery, bridge, and other locations around the village." (Hefner, 1985: 114).
"Manusia harus mengadakan pujan pada bulan purnama, tilem, galungan, panawangan, kasada, dan kapitu. Jika pujan dilaksanakan, Durga-Kala tidak akan mengganggu manusia. Ketiga Dewa tersebut terus-menerus mengajari manusia cara memuja dan memberikan sesaji kepada Durga-Kala sebagai manifestasi Sang Hyang Widhi." (Sukmawan, 2018:123).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Pujan adalah ritual pemujaan masyarakat Tengger yang berakar dari kata Sanskerta dan Jawa Kuno puja (‘penghormatan, penyembahan, dan doa’). Ritual ini merupakan bagian dari kalender desa yang dilaksanakan pada bulan tertentu setiap tahun. Dahulu berupa perjamuan besar di rumah dukun pendeta desa, kini pujan berlangsung sebagai doa singkat dan jamuan simbolik yang dihadiri pendeta serta pejabat desa dengan dukungan makanan warga. Rangkaian pujan ditutup dengan pengiriman hidangan kepada tokoh desa dan persembahan kecil di tempat sakral sebagai wujud keterlibatan spiritual komunitas.
LEXICON.translation: Pujan is a worship ritual of the Tengger community. The name rooted in the Sanskrit and Old Javanese word puja (‘respect, worship, and prayer’). This ritual is within the village calendar and is held in certain month every year. In the past, Pujan took the form of a grand feast at the village priest’s house. Today, pujan is held as a brief prayer and symbolic banquet attended by priests and village officials, with food contributed by the community. The series of pujan concludes with the distribution of dishes to village leaders and small offerings at sacred sites as a manifestation of the community’s spiritual involvement.
LEXICON.variant: Dalam bahasa Jawa klasik dan krama, puja berarti penghormatan, doa, atau sembah, dengan turunan morfologis seperti pujan (sarana atau hasil pemujaan) dan pêpujan (yang dipuja atau diagungkan). Di Tengger, pujan terspesifikasi menjadi ritual kolektif yang terikat pada siklus waktu dan struktur sosial desa, bersifat khas, dan tidak ditemukan pada komunitas Jawa lain. Meski berkerabat dengan selametan atau kenduren, pujan berbeda dalam penanggalan, peran dukun desa, dan tata persembahan yang lebih terstruktur. Dalam praktik Hindu dan Buddha, puja tetap berarti sembahyang, tetapi tanpa dimensi sosial-komunal sebagaimana di Tengger. Pujan juga telah bertransformasi dari perjamuan besar yang terbuka menjadi doa simbolik terbatas, meski tetap menuntut kontribusi kolektif. Perubahan ini mencerminkan adaptasi terhadap modernitas, dengan makna inti sebagai penghormatan ilahiah dan penjaga harmoni desa yang tetap lestari.
LEXICON.variantTranslations: In classical and krama Javanese (honorifics), puja denotes reverence, prayer, or worship, with related morphological forms such as pujan (the means or outcome of worship) and pêpujan (that which is worshipped or glorified). Among Tengger people, pujan has evolved into a distinctive collective ritual tied to the cycle of time and the village’s social structure, a practice unique to this community and not found elsewhere in Java. While related to selametan or kenduren, pujan differs in its calendar, the role of the village shaman, and the more structured nature of its offerings. In Hindu and Buddhist contexts, puja continues to signify prayer, though without the socio-communal dimension characteristic of Tengger. Over time, pujan has shifted from a large, open-air feast to a more limited, symbolic form of prayer, while still requiring collective contributions. These transformations reflect adaptation to modernity, preserving both its core meaning of divine reverence and the maintenance of sustainable village harmony.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Tradisi Tengger - Pertunjukan dalam budaya Tengger

Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. LEXICON.culturalMeaning: patung-patung bunga (petra) yang akan digunakan untuk memohon arwah leluhur yang telah meninggal. Pembuatan patung-patung petra adalah tanggung jawab wong sepuh, atau “asisten ritual sesepuh” pendeta (Hefner, 1985: 121). “petro” atau boneka laki-laki dan perempuan, yang didalamnya terdapat arwah nenek moyang (Jesper, 1927:6). Pètro adalah simbol arwah (sosok zielebeeld atau citra roh) yang dibuat untuk mewakili roh-roh leluhur, makhluk halus pelindung desa (baoereksa), dan para pendiri desa (tjakal-bakal). Pètro dihadirkan dalam berbagai upacara, termasuk pernikahan dan sedekah entas-entas (1000 hari kematian), sebagai tanda kehadiran simbolik mereka (Jasper, 1928: 73–74). "Petra merupakan simbol arwah leluhur. Petra bagian atas (kepala) terbuat dari daun tlotok yang memiliki makna telu tok, yakni lahir, urip, mati." (Sukmawan, 2018:44).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Petra dalam budaya Tengger merujuk pada patung bunga atau boneka ritual yang menjadi medium simbolik untuk mewakili arwah leluhur, roh pelindung desa, dan para pendiri kampung. Objek ini berfungsi sebagai citra roh atau sosok spiritual yang dihadirkan dalam berbagai upacara penting, seperti pernikahan, sedekah entas-entas, serta ritual pemanggilan arwah. Pembuatan petra merupakan tanggung jawab wong sepuh, yakni pendamping ritual yang memiliki otoritas spiritual dalam komunitas. Kehadiran petra menandai keterhubungan antara dunia manusia dan dunia leluhur dalam laku budaya masyarakat Tengger.
LEXICON.translation: Petra within Tengger Culture refers to a ritual flower effigy or doll that serves as a symbolic medium representing ancestral spirits, village guardian spirits, and the founders of the settlement. This object is an image of a spirit or spiritual figure invoked during various important ceremonies, such as weddings, entas-entas, and spirit summoning rituals. The making of petra is the responsibility of wong sepuh (senior residents) who are the attendants with spiritual authority within the community. The presence of petra signifies the connection between the human world and the ancestral realm of Tengger community.
LEXICON.variant: Dalam sejumlah variasi penutur dan praktik lokal, petra terkadang disebut pula dengan istilah petro, terutama ketika merujuk pada boneka ritual berwujud laki-laki dan perempuan. Meski bentuk dan sebutan dapat sedikit berbeda, fungsi simboliknya sebagai medium penghormatan terhadap arwah leluhur tetap dipertahankan. Istilah ini tidak memiliki padanan langsung dalam bahasa Indonesia umum, namun memiliki kesepadanan fungsi dengan objek-objek simbolik dalam upacara leluhur di berbagai budaya Nusantara.
LEXICON.variantTranslations: In certain local variations of speech and practice, petra is sometimes referred to as petro, particularly when referring to ritual dolls shaped as men and women. Although the forms and names may differ slightly, their symbolic function as a medium for honoring ancestral spirits remains consistent. This term has no direct equivalent in standard Indonesian, but it shares functional similarities with symbolic objects used in ancestral ceremonies across various Indonesian cultures.

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
“Each year, just after midnight on the fifteenth day of the last month of the Tengger calendar year, thousands of villagers gather in the sand flats at the base of Mt. Bromo to celebrate a religious festival called by the name of the month, Kasada.” (Hefner, 1985: 46)
“Kasada’s date is fixed in tradition so as to coincide with the full moon of the last month of the Tengger calendar year.” (Hefner, 1985: 46)
“The Kasada ceremonies culminate with the invocation of the Mt. Bromo deity and the presentation of offerings. ... No other rite, however, mobilizes people from the entire mountain territory in common ritual service.” (Hefner, 1985: 48)
“Mt. Bromo, Tengger believe, is the center of their world. According to popular opinion, the deity worshiped there is no ordinary spirit, but an ancestor turned god who gave his life so that his descendants could live in peace and harmony.” (Hefner, 1985: 49)
Kasada adalah hari raya kurban orang Tengger yang diselenggarakan pada tanggal 14, 15, atau 16, bulan Kasada, yakni pada saat bulan purnama sedang menampakkan wajahnya di lazuardi biru (Sutarto, 2006: 6). Kasada (atau Kasadha) adalah upacara puncak masyarakat Tengger yang dilaksanakan setiap tanggal 14 bulan Kasada dalam kalender Tengger. Upacara ini berupa ziarah massal ke kawah Gunung Bromo untuk mempersembahkan hasil bumi sebagai ungkapan syukur dan permohonan keselamatan (Jasper, 1928: 53–54).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Kasada adalah festival keagamaan tahunan masyarakat Tengger yang dilaksanakan pada pertengahan bulan terakhir dalam kalender Tengger, bertepatan dengan bulan purnama. Upacara ini merupakan puncak dari siklus ritual desa, ditandai dengan ziarah massal ke kawah Gunung Bromo untuk mempersembahkan hasil bumi dan sesaji sebagai bentuk syukur, permohonan keselamatan, dan penghormatan kepada leluhur yang dipercaya telah berkorban demi keturunan mereka. Kasada menjadi satu-satunya ritus yang menggerakkan seluruh masyarakat pegunungan Tengger dalam pelayanan ritual bersama, mempertegas Gunung Bromo sebagai pusat kosmologi dan spiritualitas mereka.
LEXICON.translation: Kasada is the annual religious festival of the Tengger community that is held in the middle of the last month of Tengger calendar during the full moon. This ceremony is the peak of the village ritual cycle, marked by a mass pilgrimage to the crater of Mount Bromo to offer agricultural produce and ritual food as expressions of gratitude, prayers for safety, and reverence to the ancestors who are believed to have sacrificed themselves for their descendants. Kasada is the only ritual that mobilizes the entire Tengger highland community in collective ritual service, affirming Mount Bromo as the center of their cosmology and spirituality.
LEXICON.variant: Tidak ditemukan sinonim langsung dalam bahasa Jawa umum, namun secara fungsional, Kasada memiliki kesetaraan dengan konsep upacara kurban komunal dalam tradisi agraris Nusantara, meskipun dengan struktur dan teologi yang khas.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: ongkèk (oGkE?) : I kn pikulan ing kiwa têngên nganggo sikilan ut. ambèn-ambènan (dianggo mikul gamêlan lsp). II di-[x]-[x] êngg. kn: diogak-ogak supaya rubuh. Sumber: Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: sesajen berupa hasil sawah ladang dan hewan piaraan seperti ayam, itik dan sebagainya yang diletakan dipikulan (Proyek Sasana Budaya Jakarta, 1978: 38). sesajen karangan bunga dengan pikulan (Hefner, 1985:163). Ongkèk adalah tandu bambu yang digunakan untuk mengangkut persembahan berupa hasil bumi, bunga, atau barang lainnya dalam prosesi menuju Gunung Bromo pada upacara Kasada (Jasper, 1928: 53). "Arti dari kata ongkek adalah kembang layu. Layu dapat berarti langgeng, langgeng keselamatannya serta kehidupannya. Ongkek adalah sebuah sesajen yang diberikan untuk memperingati kasada. Istilah lain dari ongkek yang disebut dalam japa mantra ialah kembang layu yang berarti ‘bakal kembang (mekar)’." (Sukmawan, 2020:9).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Ongkek adalah alat pikul bambu tradisional yang digunakan masyarakat Tengger untuk mengangkut sesajen, terutama dalam perayaan Kasada. Secara etimologis berasal dari bahasa Jawa ongkèk yang berarti pikulan kiri-kanan, istilah ini meluas dari fungsi praktis sebagai alat angkut menjadi simbol persembahan. Dalam praktiknya, ongkek digunakan untuk membawa hasil bumi, bunga, dan hewan ternak menuju tempat suci seperti kawah Gunung Bromo, sekaligus dimaknai sebagai medium penghubung antara manusia, alam, dan leluhur.
LEXICON.translation: Ongkek is a traditional bamboo carrying pole on the shoulders used by the Tengger people to transport ritual offerings, especially during the Kasada ceremony. Etymologically, the name derives from the Javanese word ongkèk, meaning a two-sided shoulder pole. The term has expanded from its practical function as a transport tool to become a symbol of offering. In practice, ongkek is used to carry agricultural produce, flowers, and livestock to sacred sites such as the crater of Mount Bromo, while also being understood as a medium that connects humans, nature, and ancestors.
LEXICON.variant: Dalam bahasa Jawa, ongkek dikenal sebagai pikulan tradisional untuk membawa benda berat dalam upacara atau kerja kolektif. Di komunitas Tengger, ongkek bermakna ritual sebagai tandu sesajen dalam perayaan Kasada. Meski serupa bentuk dan fungsi, di daerah lain digunakan istilah seperti pikulan atau tandu bambu sebagai padanan fungsional, tanpa selalu memiliki dimensi sakral sebagaimana di Tengger.
LEXICON.variantTranslations: In Javanese, ongkek refers to a traditional shoulder pole used to carry heavy objects during ceremonies or collective work. In the Tengger community, ongkek carries a ritual significance, serving as a stretcher for offerings during the Kasada celebration. While similar in form and function, other regions use terms such as pikulan or bamboo stretcher as functional equivalents, though these do not necessarily carry the sacred meaning found in Tenggerese practice.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
pasung (pasUG) : K.N. naam van een soort van gebak. -masung, Pasoeng bereiden.
Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pasoeng adalah wadah sesajen berbentuk rumah-rumahan kecil yang dibuat dari daun pisang, digunakan dalam upacara ritual Tengger sebagai tempat persembahan makanan kepada leluhur dan roh-roh. Pasoeng biasanya diisi dengan apem atau djoewadah (kue tradisional) dan menjadi bagian integral dari ritual Karo dan upacara keagamaan lainnya. (Jasper, 1928: 49). "Pasung adalah sejenis kue basah yang terbuat dari tepung beras dan dibentuk dalam sebuah kerucut dari daun pisang. Di masyarakat Tengger pasung memiliki makna filosofis "kalau sudah 'pas' diusung". Artinya seseorang yang dalam kehidupan waktunya/saatnya sudah pas/sudah tiba, maka saatnya untuk 'diusung ke makam'." (Sukmawan, 2022:53).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Pasoeng: wadah sesajen dari daun pisang berbentuk rumah kecil, diisi kue tradisional (apem, djoewadah), digunakan dalam ritual Tengger sebagai persembahan kepada leluhur dan roh. Juga merujuk pada kue basah dari tepung beras berbentuk kerucut. Bermakna simbolik tentang kesiapan seseorang menghadapi kematian (“kalau sudah pas, diusung”).
LEXICON.translation: Pasoeng is an offering container shaped like a small house from banana leaves, filled with traditional cakes (apem, djoewadah) used in Tengger rituals as offerings to ancestors and spirits. The term also refers to a cone-shaped rice flour cake that symbolizes one’s readiness to face death (“when the time has come, one will be carried away”).
LEXICON.variant: Tidak ditemukan sinonim langsung untuk pasoeng dalam bahasa Jawa atau dialek lain di Jawa Timur.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Tradisi Tengger - Sesajen dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Legèn adalah asisten atau wakil dari dukun utama dalam masyarakat Tengger yang memiliki wewenang terbatas untuk memimpin upacara kecil, terutama ketika dukun sedang menjalani puasa moetih atau tidak bisa hadir. Dalam beberapa upacara seperti sedekah Kasangga, legèn memimpin pawai keliling desa, menyebarkan air suci dan membacakan doa sambil diiringi bunyi lonceng ritual. Secara struktur, legèn berada di bawah doekoen tjilik dan berperan sebagai pelaksana teknis dalam kegiatan spiritual (Jasper, 1928: 53). "Legen adalah pembantu dukun Tengger yang bertugas mempersiapkan keperluan atau sajian yang terkait dengan kegiatan upacara. Mbok Legen adalah istri Legen yang secara faktual lebih banyak berperan dalam penyiapan sesaji." (Sukmawan, 2018:68). “...waarbij worden gevoegd: twee kleine boemboengs of kokers met legèn (palmwijn)…”(Jasper, 1928, hlm. 73)
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Legèn adalah figur pembantu spiritual dalam struktur keagamaan masyarakat Tengger yang mendampingi atau menggantikan dukun utama dalam upacara kecil, terutama ketika dukun sedang berpantang (moetih) atau berhalangan hadir. Tugasnya meliputi memimpin doa, menyebarkan air suci, dan membunyikan lonceng ritus. Dalam hierarki adat, legèn berada di bawah dukun cilik sebagai pelaksana teknis sekaligus penjaga kesinambungan ritus.
LEXICON.translation: Legèn is a spiritual assistant figure within the religious structure of the Tengger community who accompanies or substitutes the chief shaman in minor ceremonies, especially when the shaman is in a state of ritual abstinence (moetih) or unable to attend. His duties include leading prayers, sprinkling holy water, and ringing ritual bells. Within the customary hierarchy, legèn is under the young shaman who servesas a technical officiant and as a guardian of ritual continuity.
LEXICON.variant: Legèn juga bisa merujuk pada tuak manis dari pohon aren.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: prapèn (prapEn) : kn. wadhah gêni (luwêng) ing pandhe (kêmasan). Sumber: Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75. prapèn : fireplace; place for an open fire, e.g. a blacksmith's forge. See also API. Sumber: Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Prapèn adalah alat pembakar dupa (tempat membakar menyan) dalam ritus keagamaan masyarakat Tengger. Berfungsi sebagai media untuk mengantar doa, persembahan, dan komunikasi spiritual menuju alam halus, prapèn menjadi elemen penting yang hadir di samping sanggar, prasen, dan sesaji lainnya dalam setiap upacara besar seperti pernikahan, entas-entas, hingga bersih desa (Jasper, 1928: 72). Dalam sistem simbolik lokal, asap prapèn dipercaya sebagai kendaraan roh atau asap sakral yang menuntun persembahan sampai ke para leluhur atau dewa. Sukmawan menyebutnya sebagai “alat panggilan dan penghormatan terhadap arwah”. "Prapen atau pedamaran adalah tempat membakar kemenyan yang terbuat dari tanah atau logam." (Sukmawan, 2018:122).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Prapèn adalah wadah pembakar kemenyan atau dupa dalam upacara adat Jawa, khususnya masyarakat Tengger, berfungsi sebagai media doa, persembahan, dan komunikasi spiritual dengan leluhur atau kekuatan adikodrati. Terbuat dari tanah liat atau logam, prapèn diletakkan di dekat sanggar atau altar sesaji pada upacara seperti pernikahan, entas-entas, atau bersih desa. Asapnya diyakini sebagai kendaraan roh dan penghantar pesan sakral ke alam halus.
LEXICON.translation: Prapèn is an incense or frankincense burner used in Javanese customary rituals, including among Tengger community, serving as a medium for prayer, offerings, and spiritual communication with ancestors or supernatural power. Made of clay or metal, prapèn is placed near the sanggar or offering altar during ceremonies such as weddings, entas-entas, or village cleansing rites. Its smoke is believed to act as means for spirits and a conduit that conveys sacred messages to the supernatural realm.
LEXICON.variant: Istilah prapen dikenal luas di wilayah Jawa Tengah dan Jawa Timur, merujuk pada tempat pandai besi tradisional. Di beberapa daerah, terutama dalam konteks kebudayaan agraris dan ritual desa, prapen bukan sekadar bengkel besi, melainkan ruang sakral tempat ditempa alat-alat yang mengandung nilai magis atau keramat.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Tenggerees dan Lingkungannya dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: bokor : KN. metalen kom met een rand van onder als voetstuk BTDj. 12, (vrg. cêmung). Vlg. ZG. XVIII, 139 ter reiniging der vingers vóor en na het eten. pangombèn nèng °, BG. 250. gêlung bokor mêngkurêp = ° bokoran, zie ben. Vlg. anderen heet dit gêlung bukur kumurêp, Wk., van bukur, I. waluh bokor, zie waluh. jêruk bokor, een soort jěruk met zeer losse schil Rh. — bokoran, op de wijze van een bòkòr: en bijzondere wijze van opmaken van het haar, gebruikelijk als bruidskapsel. Sumber: Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Bokor adalah wadah berbentuk mangkuk besar, biasanya terbuat dari tembaga atau kuningan, yang digunakan untuk membawa sesaji atau persembahan dalam upacara adat. Dalam pernikahan Tengger, mempelai perempuan memberikan bokor berisi sirih, tembakau, dan perlengkapannya kepada mempelai pria sebagai bagian dari pertukaran hadiah pernikahan (asrah pengantèn) (Jasper, 1928: 71).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Bokor adalah wadah berbentuk mangkuk besar, biasanya dari logam seperti tembaga atau kuningan, dengan kaki penyangga di bagian bawah. Dalam budaya Jawa dan Tengger, bokor digunakan untuk membawa air, bunga, atau sesaji dalam upacara ritual, serta menjadi wadah persembahan simbolis. Pada adat pernikahan Tengger, bokor berfungsi sebagai media pertukaran antar mempelai, berisi sirih, tembakau, dan perlengkapan lain dalam prosesi asrah pengantèn.
LEXICON.translation: Bokor is a large bowl-shaped container, usually made of metal such as copper or brass, with a supporting standers at the bottom. In Javanese and Tengger culture, bokor is used to carry water, flowers, or ritual offerings, and also serves as symbolic presentations. In Tengger wedding customs, bokor functions as a medium of exchange between the bride and groom, containing betel leaves, tobacco, and other items in the wedding procession called asrah pengantèn.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari bokor wilayah yang lain.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: ancak : KN. platte vierkante schotel of hordetje van gevlochten bamboe (met pisangbladen er op als schotel gebruikt bij feestelijke gelegenheden waarop gekookte rijst met de noodige toespijzen den gasten voorgediend wordt, die dan met hun vieren of vijven daarvan eten, vrg. kêmarang, ambêng, Wk.). Ook om bv. offerspijzen op te leggen (of iets, zooals visch, op te droogen of te rooken JR.) Bab. Mat. I, 17 (vrg. èncèk JZ. II) Bab. Jo. II, 286. kaungkulan ancak, sarta dipun sawiyah, een vernederende behandeling ondergaan. ° kodhok een soort ancak Tj. I, 588. ancak agra, eign, van een Butå G. Sumber: Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Antjak adalah wadah kecil berbentuk keranjang anyaman, digunakan dalam upacara adat pernikahan masyarakat Tengger untuk menata dan mempersembahkan berbagai sesaji berupa tape, pipis, djoewadah, pisang, pinang, dan sirih. Dalam slametan pernikahan, antjak diposisikan di antara sesaji-sesaji lain seperti toempeng, boemboeng legèn, dan pipis, dan dimaknai sebagai perlambang keterbukaan, penyambutan keberkahan, serta pertautan antara ruang domestik dan kekuatan spiritual (1928: 73).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Ancak adalah wadah sesaji berbentuk persegi dari anyaman bambu yang digunakan dalam upacara adat, khususnya pernikahan Tengger, untuk menyajikan tape, pipis, jajadah, pisang, pinang, dan sirih, serta melambangkan keterbukaan dan penerimaan berkah.
LEXICON.translation: Ancak is a square-shaped offering container made of woven bamboo, used in customary ceremonies, particularly Tengger weddings, to serve fermented cassava, pipis, jajadah, bananas, areca nuts, and betel leaves, that symbolize openness and receptivity to blessings.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari Ancak wilayah yang lain.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Dalam pelaksanaan mbeduduk, daun yang digunakan untuk mengikat hewan yang akan disembelih adalah daun tlotok. Tlotok memiliki arti telu tok (hanya tiga). Daun tersebut merupakan simbol dari ajaran agama Hindu yaitu Trimurti. Trimurti sendiri merupakan pedoman hidup umat Hindu yang berisi anjuran untuk berpikir yang baik, berbicara yang baik, dan berbuat yang baik. Selain makna simbolis, penggunaan daun tlotok dirasakan lebih mudah, lentur, dan bertekstur kuat jika dibandingkan dengan daun yang lainnya. Semakin mengering, daun tlotok akan semakin kuat. Daun tlotok juga digunakan sebagai media pembuatan Petra. Petra merupakan simbol arwah leluhur. Petra bagian atas (kepala) terbuat dari daun tlotok yang memiliki makna telu tok, yakni lahir, urip, mati. "Bagian atas petra (kepala) terbuat dari daun tlotok yang memiliki makna telu tok (hanya tiga). Tlotok merujuk kepada siklus hidup manusia, yakni lahir, hidup di dunia, dan mati. Daun-daun ini disiapkan oleh Pak Sepuh (asisten dukun Tengger)." (Sukmawan, 2022: 20-21).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Tlotok adalah jenis daun yang digunakan dalam upacara adat masyarakat Tengger, terutama dalam prosesi penyembelihan hewan kurban (mbeduduk) dan pembuatan simbol arwah leluhur (petra). Nama tlotok berasal dari ungkapan "telu tok" yang berarti "hanya tiga", merujuk pada nilai-nilai spiritual Trimurti serta siklus hidup manusia: lahir, hidup, dan mati. Selain makna simboliknya, daun tlotok dipilih karena sifatnya yang lentur, kuat, dan semakin mengeras saat mengering, sehingga ideal untuk pengikatan maupun pembentukan struktur simbolik dalam ritual.
LEXICON.translation: Tlotok is a type of leaf used in the customary rituals of the Tengger community, particularly in the animal sacrifice procession (mbeduduk) and the making of ancestral spirit effigies (petra). The name tlotok derives from the expression telu tok (only three), referring to the spiritual values of the Trimurti as well as the human life cycle: birth, life, and death. Beyond its symbolic meaning, tlotok leaf is chosen for its flexibility, strength, and tendency to harden as it dries, making it ideal for binding and for shaping symbolic structures in rituals.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari Tlotok wilayah yang lain.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
sajêng (saj|G) : K.N. een soort van sterken drank, arak.
Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16. sajěng : (sajöng) an alcoholic drink; palm wine; asajěngan palm wine maker; kasajěngan drunken.
Kawi Lexicon, Wojowasito, 1980, #575. sajeng : (sajöng) minuman keras; tuak; asajěngan pembuat tuak; kasajěngan mabuk.
Kawi - Indonesia, Wojowasito, 1977, #1019.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Sadjeng adalah minuman fermentasi dari ketan yang dicampur dengan bahan beraroma kuat seperti trasi (fermentasi ikan) yang digunakan sebagai bentuk hukuman simbolik dalam permainan tjangkriman bagi siapa pun yang gagal menjawab teka-teki. Peminumnya biasanya menunjukkan ekspresi jijik yang menimbulkan tawa, menjadikan sadjeng sebagai sarana penjernih suasana sekaligus simbol penebusan ringan dalam konteks sakral. Minuman ini tidak bertujuan untuk menghina, melainkan untuk mencairkan ketegangan dan mengembalikan keseimbangan dalam permainan ritual (Jasper, 1928: 50).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Sadjeng adalah minuman fermentasi tradisional berbahan dasar ketan yang dicampur dengan unsur beraroma tajam seperti trasi, dan digunakan dalam konteks permainan tjangkriman sebagai bentuk hukuman simbolik bagi peserta yang gagal menjawab teka-teki. Penyajian sadjeng berfungsi sebagai media pencair suasana melalui ekspresi spontan peminumnya yang memancing tawa, sekaligus menjadi simbol penebusan ringan dalam ritus sakral.
LEXICON.translation: Sadjeng is a traditional fermented drink made from glutinous rice mixed with strongly scented ingredients such as shrimp paste (trasi), used in the context of the cangkriman game as a symbolic punishment for participants who fail to answer a riddle. The serving of sadjeng functions as a medium for lightening the atmosphere through the spontaneous reactions of its drinkers, which provoke laughter, while also serving as a symbol of mild atonement within the sacred rite.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari Sadjeng wilayah yang lain.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Tradisi Tengger - Sesajen dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: kasa (kOsO) : kn. mangsa kang kapisan (22 Juni - 2 Agustus). Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Bulan kesatu dalam kalender Tengger. Kasa (21 Juni - 3 Juli) ditandai ketika bayangan kaki berada di selatan dan ikan air tawar (iwak betik) memiliki satu lubang di kepalanya. Kasa adalah waktu untuk menanam tanaman (Jasper, 1928:34)
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Kasa adalah bulan pertama dalam kalender ritual Tengger, berlangsung sekitar akhir Juni hingga awal Juli, ditandai dengan posisi bayangan kaki mengarah ke selatan dan ciri alamiah ikan air tawar (betik) yang memiliki satu lubang di kepala. Bulan ini menandai dimulainya musim tanam dan menjadi penanda awal siklus pertanian dan spiritual masyarakat Tengger.
LEXICON.translation: Kasa is the first month in the Tengger ritual calendar, occurring around late June to early July, marked by the position of leg shadows pointing south and by a natural sign of the freshwater fish (betik), which has a single hole on its head. This month marks the beginning of the planting season as well as the agricultural and spiritual cycle of Tengger community.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari Kasa wilayah yang lain.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Prasen adalah wadah khusus untuk menampung tirta atau air suci dalam rangkaian upacara keagamaan di masyarakat Tengger. Dalam slametan walagara, prasen ditempatkan bersama alat upacara lainnya di dekat sesaji, dan digunakan oleh dukun untuk memercikkan air suci sebagai penanda keberkahan dan pensucian (Jasper, 1928: 72). Menurut Sutarto (2006: 10-12), prasen juga digunakan dalam upacara pernikahan dan kematian menjadikannya sebagai benda ritual yang membawa sifat pembersih dan penyambung antara dunia manusia dan dunia roh. "Prasen adalah wadah air suci. Istilah lainnya yang digunakan untuk menyebut prasen adalah siwamba, yakni tempat air wasuh padha. Air wasuh padha adalah air yang dipakai untuk menyucikan kaki para dewa/dewi dan para leluhur. Setelah itu, air tersebut dapat digunakan untuk menyucikan diri sendiri." (Sukmawan, 2018:122).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Prasen adalah wadah khusus untuk menampung tirta atau air suci dalam berbagai upacara adat masyarakat Tengger. Digunakan dalam ritual seperti walagara, pernikahan, dan kematian, prasen berfungsi sebagai medium pensucian dan penghantar berkah. Air yang ditampung dalam prasen juga dikenal sebagai air wasuh padha, yaitu air yang digunakan untuk membasuh kaki leluhur atau dewa, dan secara simbolik menyucikan manusia serta menjembatani hubungan antara alam roh dan dunia nyata.
LEXICON.translation: Prasen is a special container for tirta or holy water in various Tengger customary ceremonies. Prasen is used in rituals such as walagara, weddings, and funerary rite as a medium of purification and a conduit of blessings. The water in the prasen is referred to as air wasuh padha, which is used to wash the feet of ancestors or deities, and symbolically purifies humans while bridging the relationship between the spirit realm and the human world.
LEXICON.variant: Belum ditemukan varian atau sinonim dari prasen wilayah yang lain.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: wong (wOG) : orang, uwwèng, uwèng, nar, nra, nara, tiang, tiyang K., sujanma, sujalma, wwang, wwanga, wyajana, wyang, wyanga, wang, wong, wonga, wongha, wanggana, jana, janma, jalma, yana, manusa, manuswa, manusya, manuwya, manuja, manungsa, zie lanang en wadon; [pawongan]: kakawan, waracèthi, patiyangan, pagundhikan; Bausastra: Jarwa Kawi, Padmasusastra, 1903, #11. tênggêr : KN. hoog van een grooter of kleiner uitgestrektheid grond in vergelijking van den grond er naast of omheen (vrg. mênggêr). tênggêr-tênggêr, zva. punthuk-punthuk. gunung Tênggêr, het Těnggěr-gebergte. Sumber: Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: wong tengger in an earlier period would have meant "highland person(s)." The term tengger is no longer used in this way in modern Javanese, but is partially preserved in the Indonesian language as a verb, tengger, "to perch or sit above." In the modern Javanese language, the term is used only as a proper noun to refer to the region and people of the Tengger highlands (Hefner, 1985: 25). "Wong Tengger adalah petani tradisional yang bertempat tinggal di dataran tinggi Tengger yang setia menjalankan tradisi warisan nenek moyang mereka." (Sukmawan, 2018: 156).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Wong Tengger adalah kelompok etnis agraris yang mendiami kawasan pegunungan Tengger di Jawa Timur. Mereka dikenal sebagai penjaga tradisi leluhur yang kuat, dengan kehidupan yang berpaut erat pada sistem pertanian dataran tinggi dan praktik spiritual Hindu-Jawa. Secara etimologis, istilah ini merujuk pada “orang-orang dataran tinggi” dan kini mengacu pada identitas kultural dan geografis masyarakat Tengger secara keseluruhan.
LEXICON.translation: Wong Tengger is an agrarian ethnic group inhabiting the Tengger highlands in East Java. They are known as strong preservers of ancestral traditions whose lives are closely tied to highland agricultural systems and Javanese-Hindu spiritual practices. Etymologically, the term refers to "people of the highlands" and now denotes the cultural and geographical identity of the Tengger community as a whole.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: dhanyang (Da¥aG) : kn 1 ([x] baurêksa, [x] pakayangan) dhêmit sing mbaurêksa ing sawijining panggonan; 2 ak. sanggan ut. congkok tembok; kc. bau-dhanyang, dhanghyang. Sumber: Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Roh-roh teritorial yang dikenal sebagai danyang, roh-roh yang tidak secara khusus diidentifikasi sebagai manusia (Jasper, 1928: 23). "Danyang, pepunden, baureksa, atau leluhur adalah sosok gaib yang sangat dihormati (bukan ditakuti) oleh masyarakat Tengger karena menjadi pengayom kehidupan lahir-batin mereka." (Sukmawan, 2018:41).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Dhanyang adalah roh penjaga suatu wilayah atau tempat tertentu dalam kepercayaan masyarakat Tengger, yang tidak selalu berasosiasi dengan arwah manusia. Sosok ini dipandang sebagai entitas gaib pengayom yang menjaga keharmonisan antara alam, manusia, dan dunia roh. Dhanyang kerap diposisikan sejajar dengan baureksa, pepunden, atau leluhur, dan dihormati dalam praktik spiritual sebagai pelindung kehidupan lahir dan batin komunitas.
LEXICON.translation: Dhanyang is a guardian spirit of a particular region or place in the belief system of the Tengger community that is not always associated with human souls. This figure is regarded as a supernatural protector who maintains harmony between nature, humans, and the spirit world. Dhanyang is often positioned on the same level as baureksa, pepunden, or ancestors, and is revered in spiritual practices as a guardian of the community’s physical and spiritual life.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Agama dan Kepercayaan Tengger dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Potèn adalah tempat suci di tengah Lautan Pasir Gunung Bromo yang menjadi titik kumpul utama dalam upacara Kasada. Di sinilah para dukun memanjatkan doa bersama kepada Sunan Pernata, pelindung spiritual tempat tersebut, sebelum melanjutkan perjalanan ke kawah. Lokasi ini dikelilingi pagar sederhana dan menjadi semacam sanggar terbuka yang menghadap langsung ke kerucut Bromo (Jasper, 1928: 54). Poten adalah ruang suci berbentuk panggung upacara yang terletak di lautan pasir Gunung Bromo, menjadi pusat penyelenggaraan ritual keagamaan masyarakat Tengger, terutama pada perayaan Kasada. Poten berfungsi sebagai altar terbuka yang dilengkapi dengan perlengkapan ritus seperti prapen (tempat dupa), prasen (bejana tirta), dan berbagai sesaji (Hefner, 1989: 49-50).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Potèn adalah ruang suci berbentuk panggung upacara yang terletak di tengah Lautan Pasir Gunung Bromo, berfungsi sebagai altar utama dalam pelaksanaan upacara Kasada masyarakat Tengger. Di tempat ini, para dukun memimpin doa dan pemujaan kepada pelindung spiritual seperti Sunan Pernata, dengan menggunakan perlengkapan ritus seperti prapen (tempat dupa), prasen (bejana tirta), dan sesaji. Potèn menjadi titik pusat penghormatan, persatuan spiritual, dan komunikasi sakral antara manusia dan dunia ilahi dalam tradisi religius Tengger.
LEXICON.translation: Potèn is a sacred ceremonial space in the middle of the sand field at Mount Bromo, serving as the main altar during the Kasada ceremony in Tengger community. At this site, shamans lead prayers and worship directed toward spiritual protectors such as Sunan Pernata, using ritual implements such as prapen (incense holder), prasen (holy water vessel), and offerings. Potèn functions as the center of veneration, spiritual unity, and sacred communication between humans and the divine realm in Tengger religious tradition.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning: Etymologically derived from Javanese: 'banyu' means water and 'kurung' means to enclose or to surround. Literally, 'banyu kurung' means water used to enclose or protect something.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: In Tengger culture, 'Banyu Kurung' refers to sacred water used in purification or protection rituals. This water is usually taken from a sacred spring and blessed by a shaman or spiritual leader before being used in traditional ceremonies such as ruwatan (spiritual cleansing) or village purification rituals. The use of 'Banyu Kurung' symbolizes harmony between humans, nature, and spiritual forces that maintain balance in life.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Sacred water used for spiritual purification or protection.
LEXICON.translation: Sacred water for purification or protection.
LEXICON.variant: Banyu Suci, Banyu Berkah
LEXICON.otherDescription: Used in rituals such as ruwatan, selamatan, and purification of sacred places or objects in Tengger society.
