codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Sejarah Ponoragan dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kata pana berarti melihat secara teliti, cermat, dan raga berarti badan, dan atau diri. Berdasarkan sudut pandang ini, Ponorogo berarti melihat diri sendiri dengan cermat, atau lebih popular dengan istilah pandai mawas diri. Pandangan lain menafsirkan Panaraga berkaitan dengan istilah “panraga skar” menjadi Panaraga yang terdapat dalam prasasti Watukura tahun 902 Masehi yang berarti “persembahan bunga” (Poesponegoro & Notosusanto, 1984). Dari makna tersebut, dapat dikiaskan sebutan Ponorogo sebagai suatu ungkapan batin (sikap legawa) sebagai petanda syukur kepada Sang Pencipta atas perkenaannya berbuat sesuatu yang dapat dinikmati orang lain baik dalam bentuk lisan maupun tulisan.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Sejarah Ponoragan dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Gerakan atau polah bowo tarian warok mengajarkan kepada masyarakat luas tentang kearifan pendidikan (education wisdom), yakni bagaimana cara etika menuntut ilmu harus disertai dengan si kap, semangat, kerja keras, cerdas, dan ikhlas. Nilai ini sangat penting diterapkan oleh peserta didik di mana pun dan kapan pun mengingat pada era sekarang ini banyak siswa yang niretika dan tidak beradab dengan sikap berani pada guru, seperti melakukan berbagai kekerasan yang berujung pada penistaan dan penderitaan.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
gêmblak (g|mbla?) : I êngg. kn:gêndul cilik. II kn: tukang gawe dandanan kuningan. III (ut. [x]-an) kn: lèdhèk lanang; ng-[x]: ndhêmêni padha lanang.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

gêmblak : geelkoperwerker WG. 200; dial. = gêndul cilik, de N.
Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.

gêmblak : 1 tinker; tinsmith, brass worker; person whose trade is making things from odds and ends. 2 small bottle. 3 (or [x]-an) male performer of classical songs and dances. ng/di-[x]-(i) to have homosexual relations (with) [other males].
Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
penari bocah laki-laki rupanya cantik, pasangan warok dalam seni reog ponorogo (Adam, 1938). Anak laki-laki yang bertugas sebagai penari jathil sebagai gambaran dari prajurit berkuda kemudian pada tahun 80-an peran itu digantikan oleh perempuan. hubungan bapak dengan anak asuh karena warok membutuhkan ketenangan dalam bermeditasi. Dalam proses meditasi, salah satu pantangannya adalah menghindari berhubungan badan. Di sinilah peran gemblak melayani warok terkait segala kebutuhan warok. Jadi, orientasinya tidak homoseksual, tetapi bentuk pengabdian gemblak kepada warok. seorang anak laki-laki yang berpakaian seperti perempuan, dengan rok perempuan, penutup dada, dan anting-anting.
Anak laki-laki ini disebut gëmblakan (Peagued, 1938).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Gemblak adalah penari bocah laki-laki berpenampilan cantik yang menjadi pasangan warok dalam seni Reog Ponorogo, bertugas sebagai penari jathil yang menggambarkan prajurit berkuda dengan mengenakan pakaian layaknya perempuan lengkap dengan rok, penutup dada, dan anting-anting. Hubungan warok dengan gemblak merupakan hubungan bapak dengan anak asuh yang didasari kebutuhan spiritual, di mana warok memerlukan ketenangan dalam bermeditasi dengan pantangan menghindari hubungan badan, sehingga gemblak berperan melayani segala kebutuhan warok sebagai bentuk pengabdian, bukan orientasi homoseksual. Pada tahun 1980-an, peran gemblak sebagai penari jathil mulai digantikan oleh perempuan, menandai perubahan signifikan dalam tradisi pertunjukan Reog Ponorogo.
LEXICON.translation: Gemblak refers to a young male dancer who traditionally accompanied a warok in Reog Ponorogo performances, taking the role of the jathil, a horse-riding warrior, and wearing feminine-style attire such as a skirt, chest covering, and earrings as part of the symbolic presentation. The relationship between warok and gemblak was understood as a father–child spiritual bond, in which the warok practiced strict ascetic discipline, including abstaining from sexual relations, and the gemblak assisted the warok in daily needs as an expression of devotion rather than sexual orientation. Starting in the 1980s, the role of gemblak as jathil dancer was gradually replaced by women, marking a significant change in the Reog Ponorogo tradition.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
warok (warO?) : (ut. [x]-an) êngg. kn. wong sing kêdhot (jago kêrêngan).
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

warok : (or [x]-an) 1 one who likes to lord it over others. 2 a quarrelsome person.
Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: warok merupakan tokoh adat subetnik Panaragan yang memiliki daya linuwih ‘kelebihan’ dan berperan dalam mengembangkan nilai-nilai kearifan lokal yang sering digambarkan memiliki sifat kesatria dan teladan bagi masyarakat. Oleh karena itu, keberadaan warok sangat dihormati sehingga seringkali mereka dimintai bantuan spiritual oleh masyarakat dalam berbagai aktivitas seperti hajatan, pagelaran, maupun ritual adat tradisi. Menurut Poerwowidjoyo (1990) warok berasal dari kata waro’i atau wirangi (dalam bahasa Jawa) yang berarti wis pana wis ngerti banget, marang agal alus lahir batin, tumindake mung kangge tetulung marang liyan ‘sudah paham, terhadap lahir dan batin, tindakannya hanya untuk menolong orang lain’. Berdasarkan pengertian tersebut, dapat disimpulkan bahwa seorang warok memiliki kemampuan supranatural atau kesaktian yang di gunakan untuk menolong sesama. Pendapat lain mengenai istilah waro berasal dari kata wewarah. Kata wewarah dari bahasa arab wara yang berarti ‘menjauhkan diri dari segala syubhat’. Wewarah seringkali dimaknai wong kang sugih wewarah ‘orang yang kaya pentunjuk’. Seperti disinggung dalam banyak literatur, nilai-nilai filosofis sangat kental dalam kesenian Reog, termasuk konsep nama warok itu sendiri.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Warok merujuk pada seorang tokoh atau individu yang dianggap sakti atau memiliki kekuatan magis dalam tradisi Ponorogo. Warok sering kali diidentifikasi dengan sifat kepemimpinan yang kuat, kebijaksanaan, dan kemampuan melindungi masyarakat.
LEXICON.translation: Warok refers to a figure in Ponorogo tradition believed to possess spiritual power or supernatural abilities. A Warok is often associated with strength, wisdom, moral authority, and the responsibility to protect and guide the community.

culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)
culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Warok sepuh menggambarkan sosok berwibawa dengan membawa teken ‘tongkat’ sambil mengamati dan mengarahkan warok muda (Gambar 2.4) yang sedang berlatih ilmu kanuragan. Wujud ekspresi “pendadaran” warok sepuh kepada warok muda yang tecermin dari polah bawa ‘tingkah laku’ terungkap dari gerakan warok muda seperti sembahan, yakni bentuk penghormatan murid kepada guru. Hal ini merupakan bentuk adab mulia siswa warok dalam mencari rida seorang guru. Dari substansi makna gerakan tari ini, dapat diambil simpulan seorang warok sepuh mengajarkan ilmu keutamaan hidup dan kehidupan yang hakiki sebagai bentuk kaderisasi atau pewarisan nilai-nilai adiluhung; dan adab menuntut ilmu seorang warok muda dengan menghormati guru (warok sepuh) merupakan kunci keberhasilan seorang murid dalam menuntut ilmu.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Warok Sepuh adalah sosok warok senior berwibawa yang membawa tongkat (teken) dan berperan sebagai guru pembimbing dalam mengajarkan ilmu kanuragan serta nilai-nilai keutamaan hidup kepada warok muda sebagai bentuk kaderisasi nilai adiluhung.

culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Klanasewandana yang mencerminkan sebagai seorang pemain seni Reog. Klanasewandana berperan sebagai seorang raja dari Kerajaan Bantarangin. Raja Klanasewandana merepresentasikan sebagai tokoh yang tampan, gagah perkasa, dan sakti mandraguna. Klanasewandana dalam tariannya selalu menggunakan gaman yang bernama pecut samandiman dengan memiliki 5 jabung sayet. Secara makna, gaman representasi genggamane iman. Maksudnya, seorang pemimpin harus memiliki keimanan yang kuat dan 5 jabung sayet. Hal tersebut meru pakan representasi dari rukun Islam yang terdiri dari syahadat, salat, puasa, zakat, dan haji.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Klanasewandana adalah tokoh Raja dari Kerajaan Bantarangin dalam Reog yang direpresentasikan sebagai pemimpin tampan, gagah perkasa, dan sakti mandraguna. Dalam tariannya, ia membawa senjata pecut samandiman dengan 5 jabung sayet (cambuk bertali lima) yang melambangkan genggamane iman (pegangan iman), yakni bahwa seorang pemimpin harus memiliki keimanan kuat dengan lima prinsip Rukun Islam: syahadat, salat, puasa, zakat, dan haji.
LEXICON.translation: Klono Sewandono is the king of the Bantarangin Kingdom in the Reog tradition, portrayed as a handsome, brave, and powerful ruler. In his dance performance, he wields the Samandiman whip, which has five strands (jabung sayet), symbolizing the strength of faith. This represents the belief that a true leader must possess firm faith grounded in the five pillars of Islam: the shahada, prayer, fasting, zakat, and hajj.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
dhadhak : KW. zva. bêbuka, Wk.; volg. Wk. KN. het kleverige schadelijke vocht van sommige vruchten, dat brand, jeukte of zweren veroorzaakt, vgl. talutuh. — andhadhak, zva. nalutuh, Wk. — andhadhaki, zweren veroorzakend als boven Wk. — dhadhakên, zweren hebben ten ... selengkapnya
Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.

dhadhak (DaDa?) : [dhadhakan]: kalasesa.
Bausastra: Jarwa Kawi, Padmasusastra, 1903, #11.

dadak : KN. Waj. II, 70 een uitroep van bevreemding over iets dat onverwacht of tegen verwachting plaats vindt (K. 1, 18), ook wel met den uitroep têka, er vóór, te vertalen door zie, daar! of, in het begin van een volzin door wel, kom! of zva. geneya, en dene, ook wel ... 
Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Dadak merak/singobarong menggambarkan sebagai tokoh seorang Raja Singabarong dari Kerajaan Lodaya. Dadak Merak merupakan simbol dari dua karakter kontras antara harimau dan burung merak. Harimau memiliki kekuatan fisik yang kuat dan dikenal sebagai raja hutan. Oleh karena itu, ia sangat disegani di kalangan penduduk hutan belantara. Sementara itu, burung merak simbol dari keindahan, lemah gemulai, dan memiliki daya pikat kuat terhadap binatang lainnya. De singabarong heeft een mombakkes van licht hout (randoe of dadap) geheel inde vorm vaneen tijgerkop met open muil, beplakt met tijgervel, en voorzien vaneen sik. Op zijn nek krijgt hij een „mërak een pauw, vaak inderdaad een gehele vogel, opgezet, met uitgespreide kunstig geschikte staart tot wel een anderhalve meter hoog 'Singabarong memiliki topeng dari kayu ringan (randoe atau dadap) berbentuk kepala harimau dengan mulut terbuka, dilapisi kulit harimau, dan dilengkapi dengan janggut. Di lehernya dipasang “mërak” seekor burung merak, seringkali memang seekor burung utuh, dengan ekor yang disusun secara artistik hingga setinggi satu setengah meter'(Peagued, 1938).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Dadak Merak atau Singobarong adalah representasi Raja Singabarong dari Kerajaan Lodaya yang menggabungkan dua simbol kontras dalam satu wujud: kekuatan harimau sebagai raja hutan yang disegani dan keindahan burung merak yang lemah gemulai namun memiliki daya pikat kuat. Secara fisik, Dadak Merak berbentuk topeng kepala harimau bermulut terbuka yang terbuat dari kayu ringan (randoe atau dadap), dilapisi kulit harimau dan dilengkapi janggut, dengan burung merak utuh yang diawetkan dipasang di bagian lehernya serta ekor yang disusun secara artistik hingga mencapai ketinggian satu setengah meter
LEXICON.translation: Dadak Merak, also known as Singobarong, represents King Singabarong of the Lodaya Kingdom and unites two contrasting symbols in a single form: the strength and authority of the tiger, regarded as the ruler of the jungle, and the elegance and allure of the peacock. Physically, Dadak Merak takes the shape of a tiger head mask with an open mouth, carved from lightweight wood (such as randoe or dadap), covered with tiger skin and fitted with a beard, while a whole preserved peacock is attached at the neck with its tail arranged artistically to fan out, reaching a height of around one and a half meters.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Kesenian Ponoragan dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kerajaan Bantarangin ini berlokasi di Dusun Seboto, Desa Sumoroto, Kecamatan Kauman, Kabupaten Ponorogo. Kepercayaan ini didukung dengan temuan arkeologis berupa ratusan batu bata besar di kawasan daerah Sumoroto. Batu bata tersebut ditemukan tidak hanya pada satu tempat, tetapi juga beberapa tempat di Sumoroto. Berdasarkan temuan tersebut, dapat diperkirakan luas Kerajaan Bantarangin pada waktu itu mencapai delapan hektare.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Bantarangin merujuk pada Kerajaan Bantarangin, yang merupakan bagian dari cerita rakyat (folklore) di balik kesenian Reog Ponorogo. Kerajaan ini dipimpin oleh Prabu Klono Sewandono dan patihnya, Bujangganong, yang melamar putri Kediri, Dewi Songgolangit, dengan syarat-syarat yang kemudian menciptakan Reog. Kerajaan ini biasanya digambarkan sebagai kerajaan besar yang makmur, dan ceritanya merupakan media pembelajaran tentang asal-usul Reog Ponorogo.
LEXICON.translation: Bantarangin refers to the Bantarangin Kingdom, which appears in the folklore associated with Reog Ponorogo. The kingdom was ruled by Prabu Klono Sewandono and his prime minister, Bujangganong, who sought to propose to the princess of Kediri, Dewi Songgolangit, under conditions that ultimately led to the creation of the Reog performance tradition. Bantarangin is often portrayed as a prosperous and powerful kingdom, and its story serves as a narrative foundation for explaining the origins of Reog Ponorogo.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kendang merupakan alat musik tradisional yang terbuat dari kayu nangka atau sejenisnya dan pada setiap ujung ditutup dengan kulit lembu atau kijang. Kendang berfungsi untuk mengendalikan aba aba gerakan tari maupun iringannya, kapan memulainya, dan kapan berhentinya.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Angklung adalah alat musik tradisional yang terbuat dari bambu. Angklung Ponoragan berfungsi sebagai ritmis, berjumlah 4 buah ber laras pelog 2 buah sedang dan 2 buah berlaras selendro. Dibunyikan sebagai pengiring di sela-sela kethuk dan kenong, tetapi kadang-kadang bisa bersamaan menurut gendhing. Angklung Ponoragan berbeda dengan angklung dari daerah lain. Perbedaannya adalah angklung Panaragan memiliki jabug ‘…rumbai’ yang terdiri dari dua warna, yaitu merah dan kuning. Angklung berbunyi klung yang artinya tawadhu (mangklung). Dalam alat musik ini, diajarkan nilai rendah hati atau jangan sombong.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning:
Lomba (Reog) dilaksanakan untuk memilih penyaji terbaik berdasarkan kriteria wiraga, wirama, dan wirasa. Kriteria pertama pada aspek
gerakan tari, kriteria kedua perpaduan iringan lagu, dan kriteria terakhir dengan penghayatan setiap penokohan (Sugianto, 2024: 23).

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

culture.cityRegion: Surabaya, Malang, Ponorogo, Banyuwangi, Probolinggo, Pasuruan, Lumajang, Blora (for border areas), and Madura
culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)
culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pertunjukan Reog Ponorogo selalu menarik karena juga didukung oleh beberapa komponen musik, seperti gong, kenong, selompret, dan ketipung sehingga menimbulkan keserasian suasana menjadi lebih meriah, serta dukungan pakaian adat Ponorogo yang khas berwarna hitam dengan menggunakan ikat kepala yang terkesan membentuk suasana yang sakral, mistis, dan magis (Sugianto, 2024:21_

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kethuk dan kenong merupakan alat musik tradisional yang terbuat dari seng, dari drum bekas, serta pada bagian tengah terdapat ku ningan yang menonjol sebagai tempat yang ditabuh menggunakan alat berupa kayu yang dilapisi dengan kain atau kain pada ujung ujungnya. Representasi bahwa alat musik ini menjadi bagian penting dari pertunjukan Reog dan wajib hadir dalam mengiringi pertunjukan karena sebagai alat musik pengiring sekaligus sebagai tanda gerakan pemain Reog dengan ritme-ritme tertentu.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kempul merupakan alat musik pukul dengan cara ditabuh yang sum ber bunyinya berbentuk penon ‘mengema’. Representasi bahwa kempul berfungsi sebagai penegas ketukan atau beat dalam suatu alunan permainan musik tradisional (Gambar 2.12). Kempul apabila dipukul mengeluarkan bunyi gung atau orang menyebut kempul dengan istilah gong. Sebutan itu merupakan onomatope yang melekat kuat dari bunyi yang dihasilkannya.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Topeng yang menggambarkan penasihat raja, Potrojaya dan Potrothala. LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
topèng (topEG) : K.N. masker, mom, momaangezigt; maskerade [Ml. id.]. -anopèng, een masker dragen.
Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Topeng Klanasewandana merupakan gambaran seorang Raja tampan dan memesona dengan simbol mahkota raja (Gambar 2.6). Topeng Klanasewandana merepresentasikan sosok raja bijaksana, adil, dan sakti mandraguna. Topeng berwarna merah merupakan simbol dari kesetiaan dan keberanian dengan penampilan wajah yang mena wan gigi putih berkilau, kumis tipis, serta mata melotot sebagai bentuk ketelitian dan kecermatan kehidupan dengan penuh senyuman sebagaimana senyum gigi dan mulut dalam topeng yang identik dengan keceriaan ini. Topeng ini dalam bentuknya kini lebih bervariasi, misalnya rambut topeng terbuat dari rambut ekor kuda, yang dahulu sering menggunakan ekor sapi.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Topeng Klanasewandana adalah topeng berwarna merah bergambar Raja tampan dengan mahkota yang merepresentasikan sosok bijaksana, adil, dan sakti mandraguna. Warna merah melambangkan kesetiaan dan keberanian, dengan wajah menawan berciri gigi putih berkilau, kumis tipis, mata melotot (simbol ketelitian dan kecermatan), serta senyuman yang identik dengan keceriaan. Topeng ini kini bervariasi dengan rambut dari ekor kuda, yang dahulu menggunakan ekor sapi.
LEXICON.translation: The Klono Sewandono mask is a red mask portraying a handsome king wearing a crown, symbolizing wisdom, justice, and power. The red color represents loyalty and courage, while the facial features, including gleaming white teeth, a thin mustache, and slightly bulging eyes, convey precision, alertness, and a cheerful disposition. In contemporary practice, the mask is often adorned with horsehair, replacing the cow’s tail hair used in earlier versions.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
pêcut (p|cUt) : kn. cêmêthi garane dawa di-[x](-i): 1 disabêt(-i) ing pêcut 2 pc. digirèkake supaya mêmpêng.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

pêcut (p|cUt) : K.N. een lange zweep [Sd. zweep. Vrg. cêmêthi en têmbung]. -mêcut, met een lange zweep slaan, zweepen.
Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16.

pěcut : pěpěcut whip.
Kawi Lexicon, Wojowasito, 1980, #575.

pěcut : pěpěcut cambuk.
Kawi - Indonesia, Wojowasito, 1977, #1019.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pecut samandiman merupakan senjata pamungkas dari Prabu Klanasewandana yang berbentuk cemeti atau pecut yang digunakan ketika penaklukan dengan Raja Simobarong. Representasi tersebut menerangkan bahwa adanya kepercayaan manfaat dari pecut selain sebagai senjata pamungkas harus dilandasi dengan nilai illahiah sebagaimana yang tecermin dari jabung sayet berjumlah lima buah yang merepresentasikan rukun iman, yaitu syahadat, salat, zakat, puasa, dan haji. Menurut Mbah Tobron, pecut samandiman sebagai senjata yang ampuh sehingga mampu mengalahkan kebatilan (Gambar 2.10)
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Pecut Samandiman adalah pusaka cambuk legendaris Raja Klono Sewandono dalam kisah Reog Ponorogo yang dipercaya memiliki kesaktian, sekaligus menjadi nama kesenian pecut populer di Kota Kediri dan sekitarnya. Sebagai kesenian, Pecut Samandiman ditampilkan dalam festival, kejuaraan, dan pertunjukan yang menggabungkan seni tari dan koreografi, serta didemonstrasikan untuk menarik mobil dan menghasilkan suara keras.Coba lagi
LEXICON.translation: Pecut Samandiman is the legendary whip associated with King Klono Sewandono in the Reog Ponorogo tradition, and it also refers to a popular whip performance art found in Kediri and surrounding regions. As a cultural artifact, Pecut Samandiman is believed to hold supernatural power. As a performance practice, it appears in festivals, competitions, and staged presentations that blend choreography and rhythmic movement, and it can even be used to pull vehicles or create loud sounds.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Penutup kaki berupa jarik berlatar hitam. Jarik wiru lima me miliki makna simbolis di dalam kehidupan di dunia manusia jangan mudah serik ‘iri.’ Wiru lima manu sia berjalan jangan sampai keliru maka harus memahami rukun Islam yang berjumlah lima.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
udhêng (uD|G) : êngg. k ikêt; di-[x](-[x])-i êngg: diikêt-ikêti; ([x]-[x]-an: ikêt-ikêtan.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

udhêng gilig (uD|G gilIg) : kn rêrêngganing êndhas awujud giligan bludru lsp.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

udhêng : wrapped headdress (kr for IKÊT).
Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pengikat kepala Udheng memiliki makna simbolis mudheng. Mlati me miliki makna melang kah harus hati-hati.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Udheng gadhung mlati merujuk pada ikat kepala (udheng) khas Ponorogo dengan motif "gadung mlati". Motif ini merupakan ciri khas daerah tersebut dan umumnya digunakan sebagai pelengkap pakaian tradisional pria di Jawa.
LEXICON.translation: Udheng Gadhung Mlati is a traditional headband (udheng) from Ponorogo featuring the distinctive “gadung mlati” pattern. This pattern is characteristic of the region and is commonly worn as an accessory to complete traditional Javanese men’s attire.

kolor : KN. zva. usus-usus, band of schuif v. e. Jav. broek, waarin de usus-usus, CP., vgl. olor.
Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
kolor : string used as a belt for trousers, underwear, or pajamas. ng/di-[x]-i to equip [trousers etc.] with a string belt.
Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Senjata untuk melindungi dari bahaya. Diikatkan dalam sabuk menjadi dua bagian
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Celana longgar berwarna hitam yang menjadi bagian dari kostum warok. Bahan yang digunakan biasanya kuat dan adem, seperti Nagata Drill. Digunakan oleh para warok untuk menampilkan penampilan yang gagah dan kuat.
LEXICON.translation: Kolor refers to loose black pants that are part of the warok costume. The material used is typically strong and comfortable, such as Nagata Drill fabric. These pants are worn by the warok to create a majestic and powerful appearance during performances.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

culture.cityRegion: Surabaya, Malang, Ponorogo, Banyuwangi, Probolinggo, Pasuruan, Lumajang, Blora (for border areas), and Madura
culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)
culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pertunjukan Reog Ponorogo selalu menarik karena juga didukung oleh beberapa komponen musik, seperti gong, kenong, selompret, dan ketipung sehingga menimbulkan keserasian suasana menjadi lebih meriah, serta dukungan pakaian adat Ponorogo yang khas berwarna hitam dengan menggunakan ikat kepala yang terkesan membentuk suasana yang sakral, mistis, dan magis (Sugianto, 2024:21_

culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)
culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: lahir dari sejarah pan jang politik radikal dengan suatu tradisi pemberontakan yang telah masyhur di kalangan masyarakat Ponorogo. Dua sosok sentral dalam citra ini adalah warok dan gemblak
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Reog Wengker adalah seni Reog yang berakar dari sejarah Kerajaan Wengker di Ponorogo dengan tradisi pemberontakan yang masyhur, berpusat pada sosok warok dan gemblak. Versi kontemporer Reog Wengker dikenal sebagai "Reog Obyog" yang tampil untuk acara pribadi dengan ciri khas tersendiri, berbeda dari Reog Ponorogo yang terstandarisasi di festival.
LEXICON.translation: Reog Wengker is a form of Reog rooted in the history of the Wengker Kingdom in Ponorogo, known for its strong traditions associated with the figures of the warok and gemblak. The contemporary expression of Reog Wengker is known as Reog Obyog, which is performed at private or community events and features its own distinctive characteristics, distinguishing it from the standardized Reog Ponorogo typically presented in festival settings.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: versi Reog pertama yang berasal dari Kerjaan Bantarangin (versi kulon kali). versi ini memuat cerita dengan aktor yang kompleks dalam dramatari, seperti  Warok, Satria Kuda Jathil, patih Bujangganing, Prabu Klomosewandana, hingga Dadak MErak. alur cerita menggambarkan semua peran aktor yang ditampilkan (Harsono, 2022).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Reog Bantarangin adalah versi Reog pertama yang berasal dari Kerajaan Bantarangin (versi kulon kali) dengan struktur dramatari kompleks yang memuat tokoh-tokoh seperti Warok, Satria Kuda Jathil, Patih Bujangganing, Prabu Klomosewandana, hingga Dadak Merak dalam alur cerita yang menampilkan semua peran aktor secara pakem dan ketat.
LEXICON.translation: Reog Bantarangin is considered the earliest form of Reog, originating from the Bantarangin Kingdom (the western river bank version). It features a complex dance-drama structure with characters such as the Warok that is the horse-riding Jathil warriors, Patih Bujangganing, Prabu Klomosewandana, and Dadak Merak. This version presents the storyline with clearly defined roles for each character and follows a strict, standardized performance structure.

culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: merupakan sebuah ikon dan identitas budaya etnik Ponoragan yang menyimpan banyak makna bagi masyarakat Ponoragan, baik dari aspek religius-spiritualis, kultural, historis, ekologis, ekonomis, maupun segi politis. Perhelatan ini menampilkan berbagai kegiatan yang ada dalam masyarakat Ponorogo, seperti festival Reog nasional (FRN), larung sesaji di Telaga Ngebel, lampah ratri sewudian, ziarah makam, jamasan pusaka, bedhal pusaka, kirab pusaka, grebeg tutup sura, dan lain sebagainya yang sangat kental dengan ritual dan kearifan lokal. Ritual dalam tradisi grebeg sura sangat kental dengan aura mistis dan magis begitu sangat terasa pada bulan ini. Semua yang berbau khas subetnik Jawa Ponoragan sangat tampak, utamanya didukung kebijakan pemerintah mewajibkan ber busana khas adat Ponoragan yang serba hitam selama acara grebeg sura.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Kata pramana berarti kekuatan, rahasia hidup, sedangkan raga berarti badan, jasmani. Dari penjabaran tersebut, dapat ditafsirkan bahwa dibalik badan manusia tersimpan suatu rahasia hidup (wadi) berupa olah batin yang mantap dan mapan berkaitan dengan pengedalian nafsu manusia yang memang harus dikendalikan dengan sebaik-baiknya, meliputi sifat-sifat amarah, lawwamah, shufiyah, dan muthmainah.

The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Tenggerees dan Lingkungannya dalam budaya Tengger

subculture.greetingMeaning: "Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being"
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Tengger in Old Javanese means “highlands” (Gericke and Roorda, 1901:918), and thus the meaning of Wong Tengger would have mean persons who lived in highlands. In nowadays Java, Tengger no longer refer to that, but cover to “perch and sit above” (Hefner, 1985:25). Wong Tengger ‘Tengger People’ are indigenous community who resides and surrounds around the slope of Mountain Brahma (Bromo). The Tengger highlands locates to the northeast from Malang. There are three gates to reach there: (1) the first route is going to the north from Malang to Pasuruan or Purwodadi, we will find the main entrance Wonokitri village in Tosari district and going up to the Ngadiwono village. These regions well known as western side (brang kulon) of Tengger highlands; (2) the second route is heading to Probolinggo, we will reach the main entrance is Cemoro Lawang village (Ngadisari district) and directly overlooks mount Bromo and Tengger caldera. These gates are popularly known as eastern side (brang wetan) of Tengger highlands; (3) the third access has two kinds of gates: (1) heading to Tumpang, Malang then we will reach the Gubugklakah, and the main gate is Ngadas village; (2) heading to Lumajang, and climbing to Senduro, Ranupani. These regions are known as southern (brang kidul) of Tengger highlands.

Hong hulun Basuki Langgeng

Hong Hulun Basuki Langgeng is Tenggerese salutation. This formula consists of four words in Old Javenese: Oṅ or Om is often referred to mantra or formula praise; ṅhulun is the usual pronoun for the first person (Zoetmulder:1982). Whilst the rest of the words are still existed in modern Javanese, basuki means well-being, and laṅgĕṅ holds the meaning permanent. So, the Tenggerese salutation can be interpreted in the following: “Om, (Brahmā, Visnū, Sivā), I wish for eternal well-being”. Then, the receiver will reply: basuki laṅgĕṅ ‘well-being forever’. This salutation is given when someone visit their relatives by knocking the door or for maintaining social relationship among Tenggerese when they meet each other in market or climbing up to the Bromo.

Dukun Panḍita as divine actors 

In order to maintain the divine relationship between the people of Tengger and their deities and ancestor, the role of dukun panḍita (priest of Tengger) is central (Sukmawan, 2022:14). In the rituals that they perform, the priest is acting like the middleman who mediate the realm world to divine world. By uttering their formulas (mantra) and mentioning the means of the ritual, the priest communicates to the unseen figures to the man who dedicated their offerings to their deities or ancestors. In all the rituals that are performed by Tenggerese, the priest is the main actor. Tenggerese often call the name of the dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun. dukun as Rama. Every Tengger villages has dukun and the assistant of the dukun.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
pujăngga : tiyang ingkang sampurna kawruhipun ing bab kasusastran. Pujăngga: puja + angga, puja: nênuwun ing Gusti Allah, angga: badan. Pujăngga yèn tiyang Walandi: Professor.
Babasan lan Saloka, Anonim, 1908, #1278.
pujăngga (pujOGgO) : W. A., wong wignya kang kapatah ulah kasusastran minăngka damaring praja.
Bausastra: Jarwa Kawi, Padmasusastra, 1903, #11.
anom (anOm) : n. anèm k. kw nom. Sumber: Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Pujangga anom atau sering disebut sebagai Pujangganong yang mencerminkan sebagai panglima perang dari Kerajaan Bantarangin. Pujangganong merepresentasikan seorang panglima yang energik, lincah, dan penuh akrobatik yang secara substansi mengandung nilai luhur sebagai seorang patih yang penuh dedikasi dan tanggung jawab dalam mengatur strategi manajemen kerajaan. Maka dari itu, gerakan tari ini mencerminkan sikap cekatan nan penuh akrobatik yang mengundang banyak perhatian masyarakat. Tarian dengan aksesori topeng bermata agak melotot ini sebagai bentuk wujud kejelian, kecermatan, dan ketelitian dalam menjalankan segala titah dari sang Raja Prabu Klanasewandana (Sugianto, 2019). seorang pria dengan topeng putih setengah wajah ber hidung tumpul. Berdasarkan gambar-gambar dalam esai, dapat dikatakan bahwa ini adalah topeng Pëntoel. Namun, menurut Tuan Staugaard, ada seorang penari topeng lain yang muncul, dengan topeng hitam, yang benar-benar disebut Pëntoel (Peagud, 1938).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Pujangga Anom atau Pujangganong atau bujanganom adalah panglima perang dari Kerajaan Bantarangin yang merepresentasikan sosok pemimpin militer yang energik, lincah, dan penuh akrobatik, mencerminkan nilai luhur seorang patih yang berdedikasi tinggi dan bertanggung jawab dalam mengatur strategi manajemen kerajaan. Gerakan tarinya yang cekatan dan akrobatik sangat menarik perhatian masyarakat, dengan aksesori topeng bermata melotot sebagai simbol kejelian, kecermatan, dan ketelitian dalam menjalankan titah Raja Prabu Klanasewandana. Secara fisik, penari ini menggunakan topeng putih setengah wajah berhidung tumpul yang diidentifikasi sebagai topeng Pëntoel, meskipun menurut Tuan Staugaard terdapat penari topeng lain dengan topeng hitam yang juga disebut Pëntoel, menunjukkan adanya variasi dalam representasi tokoh ini dalam pertunjukan Reog.
LEXICON.translation: Pujangga Anom, also known as Pujangganong or Bujanganom, is a warlord figure from the Bantarangin Kingdom who embodies an energetic, agile, and acrobatic military leader, reflecting the noble qualities of a patih who is devoted and responsible in managing the kingdom's strategic affairs. His lively and acrobatic dance movements make this character especially appealing to audiences, accompanied by the use of a mask with bulging eyes as a symbol of sharpness, alertness, and precision in carrying out the commands of King Prabu Klono Sewandono. Physically, the dancer typically wears a white half-face mask with a blunt nose, identified as the Pëntoel mask, although according to Mr. Staugaard, there are also dancers who use black masks referred to by the same name, indicating variations in how this figure is represented in Reog performances.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
jathil (jaTIl) : jathilan Ngt., Sm. (M.) reyok, tlèdhèk lanang.
Javaansche Woordenlijst, De Nooy, 1893, #24.

jathil (jaTIl) : n-[x] kn njogèd nunggang jaran kepang; [x]-an: ar. tontonan jêjogèdan nganggo nunggang jaran kepang.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.

jathil : [x]-an a dance performed while astraddle a woven-bamboo horse (jaran kepang) accompanied by angklung music. n-[x] to perform this dance.
Javanese-English Dictionary, Horne, 1974, #1968.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Jathil merupakan pasukan berkuda yang menggambarkan sebagai seorang kesatria yang memiliki jiwa patriotisme untuk mengabdi totalitas untuk bangsa dan negara. Hal ini tecermin dari alur cerita dan gerak tarinya yang energik. Setidaknya, secara garis besar tari jathil memiliki dua versi sesuai kepercayaan penari terkait asal usul kesenian Reog. Versi pertama, Bantarangin yang banyak divisualisasikan dalam pentas pertunjukan festival. Versi kedua, Ki Ageng Kutu dengan Wengker yang terkenal dengan jathil Reog obyog (Sugianto, 2019). Tarian kuda yang ditararikan oleh pemura penari talèdèk lanang" 'penari laki-laki' (Peagued, 1938).
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Jathil adalah tarian pasukan berkuda yang menggambarkan sosok kesatria dengan jiwa patriotisme dan pengabdian total kepada bangsa dan negara, tercermin melalui alur cerita dan gerakan tarinya yang energik serta ditarikan oleh penari laki-laki (talèdèk lanang). Secara garis besar, tari Jathil memiliki dua versi utama sesuai kepercayaan penari tentang asal usul Reog: versi pertama adalah Bantarangin yang sering divisualisasikan dalam pentas festival, dan versi kedua adalah Ki Ageng Kutu dengan Wengker yang terkenal dengan sebutan Jathil Reog Obyog, keduanya merepresentasikan semangat kepahlawanan dan loyalitas yang kuat dalam tradisi kesenian Reog Ponorogo.
LEXICON.translation: Jathil is a cavalry dance depicting a knightly figure with patriotic spirit and unwavering devotion to the nation, expressed through its narrative and dynamic, energetic movements, traditionally performed by male dancers (talèdèk lanang). Broadly, the Jathil dance has two main versions based on different understandings of Reog’s origins: the Bantarangin version, which is commonly presented in formal festival performances, and the Ki Ageng Kutu or Wengker version, known as Jathil Reog Obyog. Both versions convey themes of heroism and steadfast loyalty within the Reog Ponorogo artistic tradition.

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
èblèk : KN. portefeuille, waar men papieren in bewaart Wk.; kleine vierkante schotel, bak of bord, van gevlochten bamboe, waar de gekookte rijst op gedaan wordt om koud te worden, of ook wel om van te eten, gew. door santri's om sêga, katela, enz. te eten (vrg. iyan, en ... selengkapnya

èblèk (EblE?) : prik. èblèg.
Bausastra Jawa, Poerwadarminta, 1939, #75.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Eblek merupakan cerminan sebagai kuda perang (Gambar 2.9). Repre sentasinya menerangkan bahwa eblek sebagai kuda tunggangan yang mengandung makna melatih mengendalikan hawa nafsu manusia. Eblek sebagai bentuk ilustrasi kuda dikenal memiliki nafsu yang tinggi. Maka dari itu, kuda selalu diberi kacamata untuk mengendalikan hawa nafsu. Begitu juga manusia harus mampu mengendalikan hawa nafsu di dalam dirinya. Oleh karena itu, digambarkan sebagai seorang prajurit yang mengendalikan kuda perang dan perang tertinggi adalah melawan hawa nafsu. Eblek terbuat dari anyaman bambu dan dihiasi seperti kuda perang. Eblek sebagai salah satu piranti pemain jathil menggambarkan prajurit berkuda yang sedang berlaga di medan perang sehingga dalam perannya, penampilan penari jathil bergerak sangat lincah.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Eblek adalah kuda dari anyaman bambu yang dihiasi seperti kuda perang, menjadi piranti penari Jathil yang menggambarkan prajurit berkuda berlaga di medan perang dengan gerakan sangat lincah. Eblek melambangkan pengendalian hawa nafsu manusia, di mana kuda yang dikenal memiliki nafsu tinggi diberi kacamata untuk mengendalikannya, sebagaimana manusia harus mampu mengendalikan hawa nafsunya—perang tertinggi adalah melawan hawa nafsu
LEXICON.translation: Eblek is a woven bamboo horse decorated to resemble a war horse, used as a prop by the Jathil dancer to depict a horseman on the battlefield through agile and dynamic movements. Eblek symbolizes the control of human desire, as horses known for their strong impulses are guided with reins or blinders, just as humans must learn to restrain their own desires and lust, which is the greatest battle of the human beings.

codificationDomain.explanation: Domain Komponen Atribut Reog dalam subculture Panaragan

subculture.greetingMeaning: We are Children of Panaraga People.
subculture.explanation:
Introduction

 Panaraga is an area that has been etched into the collective memory of Javanese history, with its ancient identity as the region of Wĕngkĕr. This is mentioned in the books Pararaton and Negara Kartagama (D.J Brandes, 1897). Etymologically, the name Wĕngkĕr derives from the phrase wĕngonan angker 'haunted place', which refers to the concept of a place filled with mystical and supernatural aura (Moelyadi, 1986). In the Serat Centhini, canto 213, as translated by Stein Callenfels, there is a narrative that strengthens the historical legacy of Panaraga, which asserts that Wĕngkĕr held an important position in the history of classical Javanese civilization and became the undeniable historical identity of Panaraga.

 Geographically, the Panaraga sub-ethnic group refers to the area in the western part of East Java Province, now known as Ponorogo Regency, stretching from the western side of Mount Wilis to eastern side of Mount Lawu. According to Junghuhn's records (1855), numerous altars and terraces resembling worship sites were discovered, which were considered by ancient Javanese society as the dwelling places of gods and sacred crowns. Valentijn (1862) provided a more detailed description that the Panaraga region stretched from Pacitan Bay on the southern coast to Sumbang Village with approximately 150 families, extending two miles east of Mount Lawu, bordered by the Indian Ocean to the south and Lodaya to the east, with the Semangi River in Sangkulang Village serving as an important geographical marker and Mount Wilis as a natural boundary between Panaraga, Nganjuk and Kediri.

 In sociocultural context, the Dutch Resident in Madiun, Lucien Adam (1938), provided interesting anthropological notes regarding the characteristics of the Panaraga sub-ethnic community: 

 The mystery of the origin of the Panaraga people has not been clearly revealed. Although they do not live in isolation from the surrounding areas, their types and characters differ from surrounding districts. People from Panaraga are more independent and self-confident, but also tough, brave, reckless, quick-tempered, and prefer to travel compared to average people in central Java.

 Adam's observations reveal the unique temperament of the Panaraga ethnic group, which differs from the general Javanese ethnic group, possessing an independent, brave, and highly adventurous spirit, represented by the figure of Warok as their sociocultural identity. Terminologically, Warok comes from the word waro'i or wirangi, which means 'already understands both physically and spiritually, whose actions are solely to help others', or from the word wewarah (Arabic: wara') which means 'to distance oneself from doubtful things', thus Warok can be interpreted as individual with supernatural power who uses their abilities for social good and holds a high status in Panaraga society. 

 The existence of Warok cannot be separated from the art of reyog—both are like two sides of a coin united in the ethnic identity of Panaraga. The word reyog itself has various debated interpretations, ranging from the onomatopoeic hypothesis of the riyeg-riyeg bamboo sound to Mbah Wo Kucing's philosophical interpretation, which states REYOG as an acronym for five spiritual elements (R: rasa kidung (feeling of song), E: engwang sukma adiluhung (noble soul's essence), Y: Yang Widhi (The Divine), O: olah kridhaning Gusti (the Lord's creative act), G: gelar gumulung kĕrsaning Kang Maha Kuasa (the unfolding of the Almighty's will)), which means that reyog is not merely a performing art but a spiritual medium that connects humans with the divine dimension through artistic expression rich in the philosophical values of the Ponorogo community.

Regardless of various etymological interpretations, the art of reyog was born from a complex socio-political context as a form of criticism by Warok Ki Ageng Kutu Suryaalam against the Majapahit government under the rule of King Brawijaya V, which was considered overly dominated by the queen consort. The phenomenon is symbolized in the form of singa barong or dadak merak—a tiger's head with a peacock's neck—which represents a subtle satire of a leadership that has lost its direction and power. 

Panaraga, with its historical and cultural identity, offers a unique depiction of cultural complexity within the mosaic of Javanese culture, featuring Warok as a central figure and reyog as an artistic expression rich in cultural and philosophical meaning. Therefore, this cultural heritage not only becomes a historical asset but also a living identity that must be continuously preserved by future generations as the proud ethnic identity of Panaraga.

culture.cityRegion: Surabaya, Malang, Ponorogo, Banyuwangi, Probolinggo, Pasuruan, Lumajang, Blora (for border areas), and Madura
culture.classification: Regional Culture (encompassing traditional arts, customs, and intangible heritage such as ludruk, reog, and gandrung dance)
culture.characteristics: East Java culture emphasizes values of mutual cooperation, politeness, and local wisdom; distinctive features include ludruk arts (folk drama), Reog Ponorogo (mask dance), Joglo Situbondo traditional house, sarong and kebaya clothing, and Hindu-Buddhist influences in the Tengger region; the society is multi-ethnic with a mix of Javanese, Madurese, and Osing, along with a focus on agriculture and Islamic traditions.

LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Wiraswara merupakan tim senggakan yang bertugas sebagai penye mangat perjuangan dalam medan perang. Tim ini merupakan salah satu faktor penting dalam kesenian Reog. Perannya sebagai seni tarik suara yang terdiri dari kumpulan beberapa orang yang bertugas memotivasi pemain Reog dengan mengalunkan nada yang khas, yaitu ha’e, ha’e ho’ya ho’ya dengan suara yang gerok ‘serak’, keras, dan kompak yang dilakukan secara bersama-sama. Senggakan dalam kesenian Reog ibarat sebuah makanan tanpa kerupuk maka tidak akan terasa kriuk tanpa senggakan. Dalam Reog festival, senggakan biasanya dinamakan sebagai wiroswara yang bertugas menceritakan lelakon atau menggambarkan alur cerita seperti dalam pewayangan atau dalam dunia orkestra luar negeri, seperti soundtrack sehingga menjadikan penampilan kesenian Reog menjadi lebih hidup dan menarik. Wiraswara ini mengandung kearifan lokal gotong-royong, kerja sama, dan kekompakan dalam hidup dan kehidupan untuk menghasilkan harmoni sosial dalam masyarakat sebagaimana wiras wara yang menghasilkan suara yang merdu nan mengandung motivasi kepada siapa pun yang mendengarkan sehingga merasa penonton maupun pemain merasa sangat terhibur

LEXICON.etymologicalMeaning:
sêlomprèt (salomprEt) : K.N. Holl. trompet; trompetter. -sêlompretan, de plaats, waar de trompetters van den Soesoehoenan te Soerakarta wonen. -panyêlomprèt, trompetter.
Javaansch-Nederduitsch Woordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1847, #16.

sêlomprèt : talomprèt, taromprèt, Holl. KN. trompet BS. 623, ZG. XVI, 102 (ook; trompetter R?). — nyêlomprèt, nalomprèt, enz. op de trompet blazen, trompetten. — panyêlomprèt, enz. het trompetten. en trompetter GR. — sêlompretan, enz. (een kindertrompet; ok de ... 
Javaansch-Nederlandsch Handwoordenboek, Gericke en Roorda, 1901, #918.
LEXICON.culturalMeaning: Trompet atau selompret merupakan alat musik yang terbuat dari kayu jati yang memiliki panjang kurang lebih 30 cm . Pada bagian ujung yang difungsikan untuk meniup, terbuat dari bahan batok kelapa. Ditiup menggunakan kepyak yang terbuat dari pupusnya pohon koprak. Representasi bahwa alat musik tiup ini berfungsi sebagai pembawa lagu atau melodi dan pemberi aba-aba sebelum gamelan dibunyikan.
LEXICON.commonMeaning: Selompret Reog adalah alat musik tiup dominan dalam kesenian Reog Ponorogo yang terbuat dari kayu jati sepanjang ±30 cm dengan ujung tiup dari batok kelapa dan kepyak dari pupus pohon koprak. Selompret menggunakan tangga nada Pelog Slendro (gabungan tangga nada Pelog dan Slendro) dengan 5 lubang nada, berfungsi sebagai pembawa melodi dan pemberi aba-aba sebelum gamelan dibunyikan.
LEXICON.translation: Selompret Reog is the primary wind instrument in Reog Ponorogo, made from teak wood about 30 cm in length, with a coconut-shell mouthpiece and a bell carved from koprak wood. It uses the Pelog Slendro scale (a blend of Pelog and Slendro tonal characteristics) and has five finger holes, serving as the main melodic instrument and providing cues to signal the entry of the gamelan ensemble.
